title: 106_hr4730
content: The Act may be cited as the "Lower Muscogee-Creek Indian Tribe of Georgia Recognition Act". The Lower Muscogee-Creek Indian Tribe of Georgia, descendants of the original Creek Indian Nation, are recognized as a sovereign tribe with over 2,500 eligible members residing in Georgia. They are political successors to the signatories of the 1832 Treaty of Washington, choosing not to be removed and continuing to operate as a distinct tribe. The Lower Muscogee-Creek Indian Tribe of Georgia, descendants of the original Creek Indian Nation, chose not to be removed and operate as a sovereign tribe with a viable tribal government. In 1972, they petitioned for Federal recognition but lacked critical historical information, leading to a denial in 1981. The Lower Muscogee-Creek Indian Tribe of Georgia's petition for Federal recognition was denied in 1981 due to technical omissions. Despite this, the Federal Government, the government of the State of Georgia, and local governments have acknowledged the tribe's political leaders as leaders of a distinct political entity. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. The term "member" refers to an enrolled member of the Lower Muscogee-Creek Indian Tribe of Georgia or an individual placed on the membership rolls in accordance with this Act. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of the Interior. The term "Tribe" refers to the Lower Muscogee-Creek Indian Tribe of Georgia. SEC. 4. FEDERAL RECOGNITION. Federal recognition is extended to the Tribe, making them eligible for all Federal benefits and services available to federally recognized Indian tribes. The Indian Reorganization Act of 1934 is applicable to the Tribe and its members. SEC. 5. RESERVATION. The Tribe can transfer land to the Secretary for trust within 2 years, establishing it as the initial reservation land. Gaming is prohibited on this land. SEC. 6. BASE MEMBERSHIP ROLL. SEC. 6. BASE MEMBERSHIP ROLL. The Tribe must submit a membership roll to the Secretary within 120 days of the Act's enactment, based on the Tribe's Constitution. Future membership is limited to lineal descendants of those on the base roll. SEC. 7. JURISDICTION. The reservation established is under Federal and tribal jurisdiction. SEC. 8. TREATIES NOT AFFECTED. SEC. 7. JURISDICTION. The reservation established under this Act is Indian country under Federal and tribal jurisdiction. SEC. 8. TREATIES NOT AFFECTED. This Act does not amend, modify, or interpret any treaty involving tribes mentioned in the Act or affect any rights secured by such treaties.
